data.text:
@GuyArms01089305 No probs - should have been put in the piece but clearly wasn't

https://t.co/HUtoLJEiWO
@whippletom Yea they had a peak at the time they should have had a low hence the excess would have been far higher if they had started to vaccinate in their summer. Again you proved my point.

@photographerXA But most of this is an artefact anyway. I don’t know how they report deaths in NZ but it seems clear that theirs some sort of bimonthly zig zag. It’s basically oscillating around zero.

@photographerXA That’s not how excess death works. It’s compared to the deaths at the  comparable month. Also, I don’t want to blind you with science, but in New Zealand they have summer at a different time to us. So the peaks you see in February are actually their summer.

@whippletom But you’re the one trying to attack others who simply see through the data you cannot even read. The fact is, there was a rise in deaths in the vulnerable 2 weeks after vaccination. This is seen in all age groups and it continues in some lower age groups with rising death rates

@whippletom That’s a clear drop in their summer season which is always when you see lower death rates. Before that was an 8% increase sustained for months! This is the timing of the initial rollout. Thanks for proving my point.

@photographerXA Obviously all this is absurd anyway, because the UKHSA did extremely careful comparisons between vaccinated and unvaccinated. But maybe they, like I, don’t have your super special data skills.
@photographerXA Cool. You see the -10% bit? That comes at a comparable point in vaccination to when we saw our winter wave. https://t.co/D3TicluDO3
